apod.explanation: This stunning starfield spans about three full moons (1.5 degrees) across the heroic northern constellation of Perseus. It holds the famous pair of open star clusters, h and Chi Persei. Also cataloged as NGC 869 (right) and NGC 884, both clusters are about 7,000 light-years away and contain stars much younger and hotter than the Sun.  Separated by only a few hundred light-years, the clusters are both 13 million years young based on the ages of their individual stars, evidence that both clusters were likely a product of the same star-forming region. Always a rewarding sight in binoculars or small telescopes, the Double Cluster is even visible to the unaided eye from dark locations.
apod.title: The Double Cluster in Perseus

solarWeather.messageBody:
## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Juice)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2025-08-07T01:50:21Z
## Message ID: 20250807-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2025-08-06T23:50Z.

Estimated speed: ~877 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 10 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 100/-22 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2025-08-06T23:50:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Juice (glancing blow). The flank of the CME will reach Juice at 2025-08-09T15:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2025-08-06T23:50:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20250807_034700_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20250807_034700_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20250807_034700_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20250807_034700_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Juice_timeline.gif


## Notes: 


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2025-08-07T00:15:13Z
## Message ID: 20250807-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2025-08-05T16:48:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20250805-AL-001).

### Notification information (STEREO A, missions near Earth)

Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 24 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2025-08-07T23:11Z and 2025-08-08T18:56Z (average arrival 2025-08-08T10:08Z) for 83% of simulations.

Additionally, the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2025-08-07T18:46Z and 2025-08-08T08:02Z (average arrival 2025-08-08T03:27Z) for 70% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 94% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 5-7 range (minor to strong).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2025-08-06_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083/20250805_164800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2025-08-06_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083/20250805_164800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2025-08-06_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083/20250805_164800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2025-08-06_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083/20250805_164800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2025-08-06_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083/20250805_164800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
This CME event is also predicted to impact BepiColombo at 2025-08-06T14:20Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2025-08-08T05:53Z, and Parker Solar Probe at 2025-08-07T12:09Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20250805-AL-001).

This CME event (2025-06-28T21:00:00-CME-001) is associated with M4.4 flare from Active Region 14168 (N04W07) with ID 2025-08-05T15:46:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2025-08-05T15:53Z.

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2025-08-06_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083/Detailed_results_20250805_164800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA083.txt
###

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 30, 2025 - August 05, 2025
##
## Message Issue Date: 2025-08-06T19:28:11Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2025-07-30T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2025-08-05T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20250806-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity reached moderate levels during this reporting period with 5 M-class flares, 1 O-type CME, and 17 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs were predicted to impact missions near Earth:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impact (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2025-07-30T04:30Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2025-08-02T04:00Z (minor impact), Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor)
                                       (see notification 20250731-AL-001).
                                       The arrival of this CME was not detected at L1.
2025-08-04T06:38Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2025-08-07T04:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 4-6 (below minor to moderate)
                                       (see notification 20250804-AL-003).
2025-08-05T16:48Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2025-08-08T06:18Z, Kp index 5-7 (minor to strong)
                                       (see notification 20250805-AL-001).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the listed locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
2025-07-30T04:30Z   BepiColombo at 2025-07-31T07:17Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2025-08-01T22:00Z (minor impact), Parker Solar Probe at 2025-08-01T03:00Z (minor impact) (see notification 20250731-AL-001).
2025-07-30T12:24Z   Juice at 2025-08-01T18:00Z (minor impact) (see notification  20250730-AL-002).
2025-07-31T05:53Z   Juice at 2025-08-02T14:00Z (minor impact) (see notification 20250731-AL-004).
2025-08-02T12:23Z   Juice at 2025-08-05T04:00Z (glancing blow), Juno at 2025-08-17T18:00Z (glancing blow), Solar Orbiter at 2025-08-04T12:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20250803-AL-001).
2025-08-03T07:00Z   Mars at 2025-08-08T00:00Z (minor impact) (see notification 20250804-AL-002).
2025-08-03T13:48Z   Juice at 2025-08-05T18:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20250804-AL-001).
2025-08-04T06:38Z   BepiColombo at 2025-08-05T08:00Z (glancing blow), OSIRIS-APEX at 2025-08-07T00:00Z (glancing blow), Parker Solar Probe at 2025-08-06T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20250804-AL-003).
2025-08-05T16:48Z   BepiColombo at 2025-08-06T14:20Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2025-08-08T05:53Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2025-08-07T12:09Z, STEREO A at 2025-08-08T11:27Z (see notification 20250805-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.67 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu at 2025-07-31T13:55Z (see notifications 20250731-AL-002, 20250731-AL-003). This event was preceded by a radiation belt enhancement first observed at 2025-07-24T13:10Z in the previous reporting period. This elevation of energetic electron flux levels was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 on 2025-07-22 and further enhanced by the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 2025-07-30. The energetic electron flux levels remained elevated, but below threshold through the end of the reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. At SOHO, the flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels were briefly elevated above background levels on 2025-08-05, but remained below threshold during the reporting period. This brief elevation in the SOHO protons channels was likely associated with the M4.4 flare from Active Region 14168 and associated C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2025-08-05T16:48Z.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this reporting period due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
2025-08-03  13:50:00  14:01:00  13:57:00   M2.9   N05E23 ( 14168 ) 
2025-08-04  04:52:00  05:05:00  04:57:00   M2.0   N05E15 ( 14168 ) 
2025-08-04  05:05:00  05:21:00  05:15:00   M1.4   N06E17 ( 14168 ) 
2025-08-05  02:00:00  02:26:00  02:12:00   M1.1   N04E02 ( 14168 ) 
2025-08-05  15:46:00  15:58:00  15:53:00   M4.4   N04W07 ( 14168 ) 

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2025-08-04T06:38Z     ~567            C                10/22                11                          STEREO A, SOHO, GOES              
2025-08-05T16:48Z     ~558            C                21/8                 36                          SOHO, STEREO A, GOES              


Non-Earth directed (POS = Plane Of Sky):
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2025-07-30T12:24Z     ~676            C               102/-13               17                          SOHO, STEREO A, GOES              
2025-07-31T01:25Z     ~1064           O               109/19                10                          SOHO, STEREO A, GOES              
2025-07-31T05:53Z     ~573            C                80/2                 13                          STEREO A, SOHO, GOES              
2025-07-31T09:00Z     ~645            C              -168/44                14                          SOHO, STEREO A, GOES              
2025-07-31T16:23Z     ~526            C               103/-36               12                          STEREO A, SOHO, GOES              
2025-08-01T13:36Z     ~570            C                61/-66               25                          SOHO, STEREO A, GOES              
2025-08-01T18:48Z     ~590            C         NONE(POS)/2                 18                          SOHO, STEREO A, GOES              
2025-08-02T04:36Z     ~562            C               124/-8                12                          SOHO, STEREO A, GOES              
2025-08-02T05:36Z     ~513            C         NONE(POS)/-40               10                          SOHO, GOES                        
2025-08-02T12:23Z     ~606            C               126/-15               18                          STEREO A, SOHO, GOES              
2025-08-03T04:38Z     ~616            C               129/-20               12                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
2025-08-03T07:00Z     ~713            C              -100/3                 11                          GOES                              
2025-08-03T13:48Z     ~845            C                87/-18               17                          SOHO, GOES                        
2025-08-03T22:36Z     ~702            C                98/-50               14                          SOHO, STEREO A, GOES              
2025-08-03T23:12Z     ~508            C                88/-60               26                          SOHO, STEREO A, GOES              
2025-08-05T07:24Z     ~809            C               112/-46               16                          SOHO, STEREO A, GOES              


## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2025-08-06T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2025-08-12T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently nine Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 14168 (N06W18) produced numerous M-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to produce similar levels of flaring activity during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. Enhancements in geomagnetic activity may be possible starting on 2025-08-07 through 2025-08-08 due to two potentially Earth-directed CMEs which were first seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2025-08-04T06:38Z and in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2025-08-05T16:48Z. A large southern coronal hole stretching approximately from longitudes W20 to E90 (as seen in available EUV imagery from SDO/AIA) began crossing the central meridian on 2025-08-05 and may reach geoeffective longitudes starting on or around 2025-08-09. Additionally, a coronal hole centered around N14E25 (as seen in available EUV imagery from SDO/AIA) is expected to cross the central meridian starting on 2025-08-07 and may reach geoeffective longitudes starting on or around 2025-08-11.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (BepiColombo, OSIRIS-APEX, Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2025-08-06T17:37:09Z
## Message ID: 20250806-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by GOES / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2025-08-06T07:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~747 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 13 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 32/10 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2025-08-06T07:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact BepiColombo, OSIRIS-APEX (glancing blow), Parker Solar Probe (glancing blow), and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The leading edge of the CME will reach BepiColombo at 2025-08-07T02:00Z, and the flank of the CME will reach OSIRIS-APEX at 2025-08-08T18:00Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2025-08-08T00:00Z, and STEREO A at 2025-08-08T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2025-08-06T07:24:00-CME-001):

## Notes: 

This CME event (2025-08-06T07:24:00-CME-001) is associated with C5.2 flare from Active Region 14168 (N05W15) with ID 2025-08-06T06:04:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2025-08-06T06:13Z.


SCORE CME typification system:

##

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / GOES / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2025-08-05T16:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~558 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 36 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 21/8 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2025-08-05T16:48:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect BepiColombo, OSIRIS-APEX, Parker Solar Probe, and STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CME will reach BepiColombo at 2025-08-06T14:20Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2025-08-08T05:53Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2025-08-07T12:09Z, and STEREO A at 2025-08-08T11:27Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2025-08-08T06:18Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 5-7 (minor to strong).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2025-08-05T16:48:00-CME-001):

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )

##

## Message ID: 20250804-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / GOES / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2025-08-04T06:38Z.

Estimated speed: ~567 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 11 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 10/22 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2025-08-04T06:38:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect BepiColombo (glancing blow), OSIRIS-APEX (glancing blow), and Parker Solar Probe (glancing blow).  The flank of the CME will reach BepiColombo at 2025-08-05T08:00Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2025-08-07T00:00Z, and Parker Solar Probe at 2025-08-06T06:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2025-08-07T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-6 (below minor to moderate).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2025-08-04T06:38:00-CME-001):

## Notes: 

This CME event (2025-08-04T06:38:00-CME-001) is associated with a double peaked M2.0 flare with ID 2025-08-04T04:52:00-FLR-001 and M1.4 flare with ID 2025-08-04T05:05:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2025-08-04T04:57Z and 2025-08-04T05:15Z respectively, both of which originated from Active Region 14168 (N05E12).

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2025-07-31T15:45:46Z
## Message ID: 20250731-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:
 
Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2025-07-31T13:55Z.
 
The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by coronal hole high speed stream which began on 2025-07-22, reaching maximum sustained speeds of approximately 740 km/s. A subsequent coronal hole high speed stream which began on 2025-07-30, reaching maximum sustained speeds of approximately 550 km/s, has further enhanced the electron fluxes. The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 410 km/s.
 
NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.
 
Activity ID: 2025-07-31T13:55:00-RBE-001.
 
## Notes:
 
This ongoing event is preceded by a radiation belt enhancement first observed at 2025-07-24T13:10Z (see notifications 20250724-AL-001, 20250726-AL-002, 20250728-AL-001, 20250730-AL-001), caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which began on 2025-07-22 reaching maximum sustained speeds of approximately 740 km/s.
